did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle:
Mana : Beyond Belief documentary film collection
2000-2004
2000-2003
did.physdesc: 47 document files in 13 folders : digital ; xls, doc, plain text, jpg, pages, pdf.
435 video files : digital ; mp4, mov, mxf.

descriptivenote.p: Transcribed: Burmese, English, French, German, Hindi, Hokkien, Italian, Japanese, Kannada, Karen, Malay, Maori, Navajo, Pali, Spanish, Swiss German, and Yoruba.
Audio only: Arabic, Cantonese, Tamil Indian, Vietnamese.

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract:
The collection consists of moving image and sound footage shot between 2000 and 2003, which led to the documentary film
MANA : Beyond Belief
(2004). Paper and electronic documents created during production and post-production are also included (logs, translations, shot lists, and notes).

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Peter Friedman and Roger Manley, Purchase/Gift; 2018.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: One accrual received in August 2021. All collection materials from the original acquisition and the accrual are described in this finding aid.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Farrah Cundiff in 2021. Digital ingest was performed by Steven Berkley, Ying-Ting "Serena" Chiu, and Farrah Cundiff from 2020 to 2021.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

Non-commercial Creative Commons use is allowed and must attribute the rights holders with the following credit: "from
MANA : Beyond Belief
, a film by Peter Friedman and Roger Manley, © Peter Friedman and Roger Manley."
Permission of the rights holders must be obtained for all other uses.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Mana : Beyond Belief documentary film collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
.
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Mana : Beyond Belief documentary film collection (AFC 2019/001), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
Peter Friedman
bioghist.p:
Producer/director Peter Friedman has won many of the top awards for documentary film in the USA and Europe, and he has served on the competion juries of major European film festivals. Friedman's films include
Wizard of the Strings
(1985),
Silverlake Life: The View From Here
(1993), and
Death by Design
(1997).

bioghist.head: Roger Manley
bioghist.p:
Producer/director Roger Manley's books, exhibitions, and documentation of the folklife of indigenous peoples have earned him international recognition in the fields of outsider art, anthropology, and photography. His books include
Signs and Wonders: Outsider Art Inside North Carolina
(1989),
The Tree of Life: the Inaugural Exhibition of the American Visionary Art Museum
(1996), and
Self-Made Worlds: Visionary Folk Art Environments
(1997).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
The collection consists of the moving image and sound footage, shot between 2000 and 2003, which led to the documentary film
MANA : Beyond Belief
(2004). Documents created during production and post-production are also included (logs, translations, shot lists, and notes).

Peter Friedman and Roger Manley describe the project as an "[investigation of] the myriad ways in which people around the world invest objects with special meaning or power. The power of objects is a familiar concept to the Maori people of New Zealand, who call it
mana
. There is no exact equivalent in other languages, but mana means something like 'prestige.' Objects with mana are as diverse as humanity itself, and may embody many different kinds of power and value--religious, artistic, economic, historical, or personal. But mana itself is universal--all people, all over the world, value or venerate something."

The 114 hours of raw footage depict object veneration in Italy, Japan, Benin, France, the United States, the Navajo Nation, Malaysia, Burma, India, New Zealand, and Germany. The footage encompasses subjects such as: a rare exhibition of the Holy Shroud of Turin; the Fushimi Inari Taisha shrine in Kyoto; vodou ceremonies and The Door of No Return in Ouidah; the holy dirt of Chimayo; Navajo hogan and sweat lodge ceremonies; a modern-day dime museum in Baltimore; the one-year anniversary ceremony held at the ruins of the World Trade Center twin towers in New York city; Hindu idol-anointing in Penang; Shwedagon Pagoda in Rangoon; a Burmese car-blessing shrine; an Indian IT company in Bangalore; several interviews in New Zealand about the Maori concept of mana; fine art analysis in Berlin; and more.

The collection materials are primarily in English and French, with at least 19 additional languages recorded in ambient speech and interviews: Arabic, Burmese, Cantonese, German, Hindi, Hokkien, Italian, Japanese, Kannada, Karen, Malay, Maori, Navajo, Pali, Spanish, Swiss German, Tamil Indian, Vietnamese, and Yoruba.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Mana : Beyond Belief documentary film collection is organized in 11 series:

Arrangement of series is chronological, according to date of filming. This preserves the filmmakers' chronological tape-numbering system and the multiple cross-references to those numbers in documents. Series 1: Mixed Locations consists of documents which describe multiple filming locations or production as a whole. The remaining 10 series outline the 10 countries in which filming took place; these consist of all manuscript, video, and audio materials which relate to a given location. Materials which depict two locations are listed twice in each relevant series or subseries.
Quoted text comes directly from creators' notes. Geographic names are spelled according to the Library of Congress Name Authority File.

Video tapes include sound. Audio tapes captured higher resolution audio which generally syncs to the same tracks on video. Digital copies of all tapes exist; these are the primary way to access footage, by referencing the Digital File ID listed under each tape in the Container List below. Digital copies of video are available in three sizes: H264 (.mp4), ProRes (.mov), and Preservation (.mov or .mxf). Digital copies of audio are available in one format: (.wav).

Digital manuscript processing included the creation of a PDF/A preservation copy of each digital document in the collection. Preservation copies and original files can be accessed by referencing the Digital Folder IDs in the Container List below.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

odd.head: Appendix: Tape Inscriptions and Details
odd.p:
Attached is a
searchable PDF list
of the notes written on tape labels by the filmmakers. The information from their inscriptions about subject matter, location, and date have been incorporated throughout this finding aid, but are also listed verbatim in the Appendix for reference. The filmmakers' notes on recording specifications were not incorporated into the finding aid, but are listed in a separate column in the Appendix for reference.
